heisig_story: Note the drop here in the king's scepter, which is exactly what you would expect it to be: a precious jewel handed down from of old as a symbol of his wealth and power.
koohiiStory1: The king is said to have only one family jewel below the belt...
koohiiStory2: The king is said to have only one family jewel below the belt...and he hangs left! (I always screw up the direction of the "drop").
WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: The king has something in his hand that he's dropping... but it bounces too! He's bouncing a ball
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: This kanji looks just like a king bouncing a ball, no? If not, imagine the kanji itself bouncing the drop (the ball) over and over again, then laying some hoops like a pro.

origin_of_ch_char_book: Ancient eastern people worshiped the earth. So, they tried to preserve the natural land rather than cultivate and develop it. They thought of the earth as their mother because all the creatures come from the earth. (Èáå, li, place, inside) The upper one (Áî∞, tian=t‚Äôien, field) means field divided into four places, and lower one (Âúü, tu, soil) means the earth on which some corps are rising, and it also means an altar people gathering. The whole character means the village where people gather in the field, performing rites. In the past, people considered that the earth of their hometown would protect them, and they worshiped the god of their own territory by building an altar. This god of hometown would judge the people of the village whether to go to Heaven or to go to hell. (ÁêÜ, li, manage, reason) The left side of the symbol (Áéâ, yu=y√º, jade) is a jade bead, and the right side is a village where people live together. The ancient people believed that the jade are so pure than any other existences of the earth, and they believed that the jade is a soul of the land which can defeat the evil spirits. Because jade (Áéâ) can judge people of the village with the spirit of the earth (Âúü), is used as a meaning of control, manage, reason etc.
humanum_full_description_en:
Elaboration: The oracle bone inscriptions are shaped like pieces of jade with a string of silk threads, ranging from three to five pieces. The original meaning is jade. Wang Guowei believes that the ancient system has five jade pieces in one series, and two series as a "Áé®", and the shape of the oracle bone from the three horizontal lines is a symbolic stroke. " Jade " or Jianshang the upper and lower ends of the vertical pen. Refer to "Áé®", "Â∏Ø". Inscriptions are used as the original meaning to express sacrifices.

The inscription " Jade " runs from the "‰∏®" through the three horizontal paintings. The three paintings are equal, and the shape is like the " king " in regular script, which is the same as the small seal. Bronze inscriptions are also used as the original meaning of jade, such as Mu Gongding "Five Grades of Yiyu" and Mao Gongding "Yuhuan Yuga".

In order to distinguish the characters of the Warring States Period from the character "Áéã", one or two oblique pens or dots were added as a distinguishing symbol, which was based on the form of the later Likai characters.

An example of using the original meaning in ancient books is "Poetry. Qin Feng. "Zhongnan": "The general will wear jade, and the life test will not die." "Shan Hai Jing. "South Mountain Jing": "Five hundred miles east, it is called the mountain of Pugou, which is rich in gold and jade, and underneath it is rich in vegetation, without birds and beasts, and without water."

" Jade " also means beautiful and precious. Yu Yue in the Qing Dynasty "Quan Jing Ping Yi. "Er Ya": "The words of the ancients, wherever they are beautiful, they are in jade. The "Jade Food" in "Shangshu", the "Jade Girl" in "Book of Rites", and the "Jade Ornaments" in "Yi Li" ." Such as "Selected Works. Song Yu "Goddess Fu": "The appearance is full and graceful, and the buds are gentle and moist."

" Jade " can be described as crystal clear and white. Such as "The Songs of the Chu. "Li Sao": "The jade scorpion is a scorpion, and the wind surpasses it." It is also a metaphor for a crystal clear white thing. For example, Huang Tingjian of the Song Dynasty "Nian Nujiao": "Where is Heng'e in the blue sky, drive this round of jade."

" Jade " can also be used as a respectful word to honor others' bodies. Such as "Mandarin. "Wu Yu": "The heavenly king personally approached the jade toe, practiced with the solitary sentence of the heart, and forgave it." "Zhao Ce IV": "Stolen self forgiveness, and I am afraid that the Queen Mother's jade body may be too bad, so I wish to see the Queen Mother."

(1) Warm and shiny beautiful stone.

(10) Cherish; treasure.
(11) Help and discipline.
(12) The name given to the prime minister to the military handsome woman in the Taiping Heavenly Kingdom.
(13) Dialects. Make, make bend.
